sub_title: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
summary:
My great joy is the creation of an inspiring learning and teaching experience and environment at educational institutions which are interested to stimulate creativity and wonderment in young adults for a better future. This could either be geared directly as artistic skills and craftsmanship in an academy or, indirectly and more broadly, as a free and creative mindset in educational environments beyond the traditional arts. 

Through the multitude of projects that I have been involved in, I am well connected to a large international network of professionals within both the academic as well as practicing community in the fields of art, design, fashion, and architecture. 

I have been described as an efficient and practical, proactive, and result-oriented team player with a sense of leadership. One of my strengths is to inspire others through my enthusiasm for content and vision and convey a sense of passion that draws in and unites forces. My core experiences and abilities include everyday management in an educational and cultural institution, supervising a team of professionals (internal/ external) and support staff in an enabling, cooperative, and inclusive style: focused on connecting people, yet allowing for differences; asking questions and listening; acting as a coach but also capable of taking decisions and setting boundaries, implementing and continuous development of ambitions and a vision, carrying final responsibility for curriculum and its execution, budget responsibility, establishing and maintaining an external professional network, representing the ambitions and vision in the fields of art & design education.

I have been contributing to and curating many exhibitions, have been teaching at various universities worldwide, and have written numerous articles and published books on a wide range of topics.

projects.title: 5 Seconds Street
projects.description:
What would a neighbourhood or street look like if designed for full speed and direct accessibility? How then would our streets need to be designed? And in what way could our buildings adapt to speed and direct accessibility? What technologies then are needed? And how will these new technologies influence the design of our streets and buildings? 
In what way could buildings adapt to these transportation modes? How to speed up and make it safe? 
What strategies and new concepts of living can we think of when transportation and infrastructure becomes an integral part of the building? Could we think of vehicles that even transform into furniture? What kind of architectures can accommodate and facilitate such a hyper-mobile society? 

The 5 Seconds Street studio explored these questions and visualised answers by taking an existing street as a case study. In addition to the architectural and infrastructural components this studio aimed at understanding and identifying the environmental, social and spatial qualities and benefits of various transportation modes.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Hong Kong Super Mixers - New Vertical Living Strategies for Hong Kong
projects.description:
Almost everyone in Hong Kong seem to live in a congested flat with little space and poor conditions for domestic activities due to Hong Kong’s inherent weakness of lacking flat land for residential use, which makes property prices go through the roof. Due to demographic, political and economic forces, and the many restricting building regulations Hong Kong seem to suffer from a monotonous and unfulfilling housing market. The government as well developers and architects seem to struggle to foster diversity and community values. Low-rise developments are disappearing rapidly and replaced by monotonous money-making extrusions of simple tower floor plans. Unfortunately, Hong Kong’s housing market has become a tense investment market where diversity, community values and living conditions seem to have lost their meaning. How can Hong Kong’s housing development escape its unrelenting uniformity and the denial of diversity? How can Hong Kong benefit from its scarcity of land and population density?
Can we re-invent the Hong Kong housing tower by vertically mixing various programs and with it create more porous towers and a more 3 dimensional city? What housing towers appear when various other activities and program are integrated? What vertical organization is then needed? What vertical communities could emerge? What community values and living qualities can be discovered? And what kind of architecture can accommodate and facilitate the proposed mixed program?
This studio explored and investigated the potential of mixed-use housing towers and showcased various spatial concepts for vertical integration of mixed program. Students studied and explored new forms of vertical living strategies by mixing housing program with additional program such as farming, recreation, culture, sports, nature, education and shopping. Students investigated the motives and spatial and social qualities of vertical mixing. A series of first attempts of mixed-use housing towers have been produced.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
Environmental design, Computational Design and Digital fabrication

projects.title: Beyond Extrusion
projects.description:
Fall Semester Studio: Architecture and Urban Design III (ARCH 5001)

The housing market in Hong Kong seems to be dominated by the standard norm of a monotonous vertical extrusion of the most efficient and most profitable floor plan. In contrast to other global cities, the repetitive design lacks variation in size of units, outdoor space, diversity in typologies, ecology as well as architectural excitement. 
How to add more value by creative design? And which design parameters will then lead to housing towers beyond the current extrusion model? 
This studio is a follow up on previous studio 'Hong Kong Tower Revolution' and aims at exploring various concepts for housing towers beyond extrusion. This will be done in two phases. 
Phase 1 will study the organization and layout of apartments by investigating everyday activities such as cooking, dining, bathing, sleeping, storing, relaxing, studying and propose improvements of these activities. These improvement ask for specific architectural elements and lead to new exciting apartment typologies.
Phase 2 will explore and identify various motives for housing towers that go beyond the current standard of monotonous extrusion. From this research, a new approach on the design of these motives beyond extrusion such as vertical transportation, the maximum building envelope, mix of (collective) program, the (structural) core, will be tested. 
The outcome of this phase will be combined with the improved apartments of the first phase, resulting in a set of attractive housing towers that reflect the desired variation and diversity.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
Gebiedsontwikkelaar at SITE urban development
Environmental design, Computational Design and Digital fabrication

projects.title: 3D Nature
projects.description:
Can we imagine a city that is built with nature instead against it? Can we ‘help’ nature to become urban? And vice versa, our cities to become more natural? Can we create a 3D Nature beyond the green façade? Can we design buildings that produce nature?
The studio 3D Nature wants to explore nature as a building tool by studying different ecology and identifying those natural elements and attributes, with which we can upgrade our cities and buildings and turn them into producers of (new) nature.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
Environmental design, Computational Design and Digital fabrication

projects.title: The Willow House
projects.description:
MA Design Workshop, Fall Semester 2013, Faculty of Architecture, TU Delft (NL), Ecole National Supérieure d’Architecture de Versailles (ENSAV), Paris (F)

Commissioner: Municipality Delft

This Workshop is part of the 3D Nature project and explores how to use an organic material - willows - to grow architecture. It aims at exploring various techniques for growing such as grafting and weaving in order to design a house that functions. Students were asked to develop an architectural design proposal for a site in Delft with a plot size of 300m2 of which 22% was allowed to be built.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Hong Kong Tower Revolution
projects.description:
Fall Semester Studio: Architecture and Urban Design III (ARCH 5001)

Hong Kong’s current housing tower design is heavily governed by the development potentials / controls under the Hong Kong Planning Ordinance and the Building Ordinance. In contrast with the competition with other global cities, the repetitive design seem to lack size variation, outdoor spaces, diversity, greenness, ecology as well as a lack of architectural excitement. How can Hong Kong’s housing escape its unrelenting uniformity and the denial of diversity? How to escape from the current stringent planning and building regulations? How to create more qualities? And what qualities should that be?
This studio studied the organization of apartments and looked into the different types of rooms and their functions. It explored various activities such as cooking, dining, bathing, sleeping, storing, relaxing and made proposals for improvement of these activities. Each improvement required a specific spatial quality and led to new apartment typologies. Some qualities included higher ceilings, more window openings, different room shapes, more outdoor spaces or more privacy. Other qualities asked for different connections, better natural cooling, more sustainable measures or better access and views to the outdoor. This studio opened the discussion for a more diverse housing development and proposed various motives for both horizontal and vertical mixing that led to housing towers with a higher amount of porosity (open space). It showcased 30 alternative residential tower typology designs that can be understood as a first step to add more diversity to the Hong Kong housing market. The towers were measured against value indicators such as view, direct sunlight, indirect light, access to outdoor space, and amount of useable space.
The studio results were exhibited at the 2013 Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism/ Architecture (UABB) in Hong Kong.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

Environmental design, Computational Design and Digital fabrication

projects.title: The Porous City - Opening The Hong Kong Tower
projects.description:
Master Class Workshop, Hong Kong PolyU, HKDI, City University of Hong Kong. 
Venue: Hong Kong Design Centre.

This workshop explored new organizational principles of large structures, exemplified with a high-rise building. It was carried out by systematic manipulations of the correlations between private and public spheres, respectively represented in an abstract way by closed and open pixels. Four thematic experiments (tunnels, balconies, stairs, caves) were conducted with the premise that their results should remain abstract, binary and measurable. The towers addressed interrelations between open, closed, empty and full and generated a deeper understanding of porosity in buildings.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Postopia
projects.description:
Master Class Design Workshop, TU Delft (NL), ENSA-V, Paris (F)

This workshop is an explorative exercise to understand core characteristics of past utopias & ideal city concepts. Students collected & categorized historical examples & specific theoretical details of utopias, filtered their main societal characteristics & formulated principles for spatial organizations and capacities. This collection is a first step to establish an archive that consists of an extensive thematic bibliography including historical, discursive, practical & theoretical material contextualizing the Ideal City and Utopia across cultural, temporal and geographical boundaries. This workshop worked out 9 different utopian models. It took Rotterdam as a test-case to make the results comparable. How would Rotterdam look like if based on principles of a utopia?

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: 4 Minutes City - Capacities
projects.description:
This studio is a negotiation between the time needed to travel and space occupied by program, facilities and infrastructure. Students were asked to minimize the time needed to travel, minimize the space occupied by structure (closest to neighbor) & infrastructure and to create door-to-door accessibility for all inhabitants and users. 
The model developed generates and evaluates different options that either optimize the time needed to travel or the volume occupied by the program. The chosen model is the most successful negotiation between spatial compactness, proximity, minimum travel distance and capacity of infrastructure.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: 4 Minutes City - Housing Detail
projects.description: This research and design studio zooms into the architecture of a city that is built upon speed and direct accessibility. What kind of architecture can accommodate speed and performance of high speed vehicles? How is organization and apartment layout change according to the different vehicles used? This studio is a negotiation between the time needed to travel and space occupied by structure and infrastructure. Using the data produced on the previous 4 Minutes City studios, a selection was made to scale the data of Rotterdam into a 250 people apartment block. The model developed generates and evaluates different options that optimize either the time needed to travel or the volume occupied by the program. The students were asked to minimize the time needed to travel, minimize the space occupied by structure (closest to neighbor) & infrastructure and to create door-to-door accessibility for all inhabitants and users. For the initial model the scenario of leaving your house towards an exit point is used.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: 4 Minutes City - The Urban Plan
projects.description: Can we develop a city that is entirely devoted to fast transit of people and goods? What systems and what architecture allow high-speed traveling and a smart circulation of goods? How can the positioning of program and its architecture contribute to direct accessibility or the desire for a minimum travel time? What can we say about safety issues? How can architecture anticipate in this? This studio focused on innovative transportation techniques and their supportive infrastructure. Students were asked to conceptualize and construct city models with a maximum travel time of 4 minutes, from and to any location in the city. Each student limited his/her focus on a single transport mode throughout the city.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: The Next City - Future Living and Lifestyle
projects.description:
This project was initiated to foster international cooperation between China and The Netherlands. 
It brought together renowned research and design institutions in the fields of fashion, product design, graphic design and architecture in order to enable a cross-cultural exchange on different qualitative as well as quantitative approaches towards research and design methodologies. Participants of this anticipatory research engaged a discussion on the fate of our contemporary cities - their shortenings, fears, advantages, beauties and opportunities.
The challenge of this studio was to explore and identify significant research and design directions within the different fields of knowledge and bring together various interpretations, visions and scales within the context of future city life. 

Collaborating institutes: Technical University Delft (The Netherlands), Central Acadamy of Fine Arts Beijing (CAFA, China), Tsinghua University Bejing (China), Beijing Institute of Fashion Technology (BIFT, China), ArtEZ Fashion Master Arnhem (NL), Design Academy Eindhoven (DAE, The Netherlands), Sandberg Institute (The Netherlands).

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Varosha! Re-Inventing Cyprus
projects.description: Varosha! is set up as a parametric driven research and design studio to investigate on possibilities for the rehabilitation of Famagusta. The aim is to create a variety of scenarios for not just Famagusta residents but for the entire island of Cyprus by using the UN Bufferzone as a catalyst for new developments and change. Why not appointing the UN buffer zone as a third state, as a starting point for new developments that is based on collaboration, shared interests and common environmental and economical problems? This studio is an attempt to reinvent Cyprus by using the potentials and opportunity of the abandoned border zone.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: The Next City Symposium, Delft
projects.description:
The Next City Symposium discussed the role of design(ers) in (future) city development. Designers, researchers and engineers from different disciplines were invited to talk about the key forces of shaping the next city and society.
Speakers: Winy Maas, Tihamér Salij, John Körmeling, Paul Hughes, Christopher Zelov and Gilbert van der Lee. 
Program and Moderation: Tihamér Salij

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Robotic City
projects.description:
Can we think of a future where the city grows by itself driven by its own and by human desire? Will cities become smart enough to support sudden change? What kind of cities can we think of? Soft Cities? Growing Cities? Self Healing Cities? Hyper-Automated City? Self-Destructible Cities? Hyper-Transformable Cities? Cyborg Cities? Matrix Cities? 
What happens to the buildings? Transformer architecture or on the contrary, blank-white screen-architecture onto which different ideas can be projected? How smart can the city and its architecture be? Can the city adapt to the needs of its inhabitant? 
This studio focused on exploring urban products that change the city, its architectures, make it smarter and more effective.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: Hong Kong Fantasies
projects.description:
All cities and regions are a result of different development formulae or models. The more successful cities are those that have based their planning on economic patterns and territorial understandings. 
This studio postulates that the formula may be found by diversifying the city’s core activities. Hong Kong will be used as a case study. Students are asked to formulate a variety of future scenarios by following possible speculative urban trends for Hong Kong. This studio explores the type of urbanity Hong Kong will need to change. In particular, it focuses on the topics of concern potentially needed to bring future spatial change to Hong Kong.

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: World Wonders 1.0
projects.description:
By contemplating the wonders of the ancient world, and analyzing the modern world wonders, this studio established four elemental keywords from which the students explored the many dreams of architectural fantastications: scale, technology, iconography and myth.
These keywords served as design factors in order to challenge and constitute the wonder.
Do you dare to design the next world wonder?

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
Director & Founder SHAU Bandung-Rotterdam

projects.title: Las Palmas Experience
projects.description: The Wilhelminapier can be seen as an upcoming centerpart of Rotterdam with enormous ambitions to become the best place to be, to live, work and have fun at the many cultural events and restaurants located on the pier. It is a unique part of Rotterdam; it combines the present and the past, old warehouses with modern architecture and life style. The warehouse 'Las Palmas' is now giving space to the Beeldfabriek which is an educational institution and the Photomuseum Rotterdam. The rest of the building will be occupied by offices. A purely cultural building with a very strong identity has been degraded to an ordinary office building without much cultural spirit and power to resurrect the area. How to re-invent a cultural place with a strong identity? How to make this dream called 'Little Manhattan at the Maas' come true? 'Las Palmas Experience' adds an urban quality to the pier. The roof of the Las Palmas building located in the center of the Wilhelminapier gets accessible by placing a wooden dock-like structure on top, which is connected by escalators on each side of the building. It becomes a round-the-clock up-lifted public plaza. The usability of this plaza is diverse. The flexible structure gives space to public and private functions, whereas the plain design makes it easy practicable to ensure the potentials of the dream. It absorbs a healthy mix of culture, commerce and leisure. It is surprising at any moment of the day and night. A real revelation to all the people with all kinds of expectations, from young to old, from local inhabitants to employers to tourists and investors. 'Las Palmas Experience' is a real urban meeting point - a cultural stage for the city of Rotterdam with an enormous force of attraction. All kinds of cultural institution can use this plaza as a satellite. Different programs varying from local to regional and to international events can take place on this unique urban plaza. The warehouse 'Las Palmas' becomes a cultural magnet again!

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies

projects.title: The Bid 2.0 The Future Stadium NL 2028
projects.description: Olympic Games can be seen as a motor for new urban developments. The bottleneck of such vast investments is the after use of its large-scale stadiums. What can we do to avoid that stadiums turn into so-called “white elephants”? Munich, Athens, Sydney, Barcelona and Beijing invested heavily in creating landmarks but most of these stadiums are used infrequently. This studio researches and designs possibilities for combining Olympic venues considering a long-term urban program. Can the stadium be used for housing and offices? How? Can it become a giant mall? Or even a city? What are the benefits?

contributors.headline: Dean/ Director at Faculty for Nature, Food & Urban Green Studies
Owner JA Joubert Architecture b.v.
Director & Founder SHAU Bandung-Rotterdam

projects.title: The Bid 1.0 Future Olympics NL 2028
projects.description: A Healthy city? Can it exist? What components are needed to do that? This studio investigates the feasibility of a Netherlands Olympics, looking at themes like climate change, water management and energy production, as well as innovative ideas for stadiums, infrastructure and athlete accommodation. What is the speculative ability of the Olympic Games for 2028 in the Netherlands? This studio explores the possibilities of the ideal Olympics by analyzing and speculating on its program, time frame and spatial requirements.

profile_positions.title: Head of Department of Fine Art a.i.

profile_positions.description:
This year's George Verberg stipend has been awarded to Anna Fitas. The stipend consists of a prize of € 10,000 and was established to support young, talented artists in their development abroad. The jury has nominated three candidates from fourteen applications. The jury has noticed that all candidates have an international orientation and will research hidden subcultures and innovative forms of presentation. The artists give substance to questions such as: "What nostalgic memories do we have and how do cultures influence the choice of materials, media and performances?” 
In addition to the name-giver George Verberg, this year's jury consists of Dorothea van der Meulen (Dean of Minerva Academy and chair of the jury), Tihamér Salij (head of Fine Art and Workshops), Sarianne Breuker (lecturer in Fine Art) and Frederiek Bennema (lecturer in theory courses).

Anna Fitas
Anna surprised the jury with her excellent research question, beautiful presentation and artistic vision. Anna will relate the worlds of light and dark to man and the current theme of climate change. Through new stories, images and starting points, Anna will set to work with the aim of making a contribution to raising awareness about climate change. The jury expects the grant to make a special contribution to the further development of her artistic calling.

profile_positions.description:
Space Intelligence Agency prides itself on not being a conventional architecture & urban research & design office. S.I.A. brings together many research and design disciplines in an interactive collective. It enables research and design institutions, designers, and thinkers from different cultures, sciences, and design disciplines to fertilize the discussion on the fate of our contemporary societies and cities, their architectures, infrastructures, and products. S.I.A. explores, designs, and visualizes new and alternative models for both society and the city. S.I.A. studies possible living strategies and lifestyles and formulates the spatial, social, economic, and ecological qualities, analyzing its strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats. S.I.A. has been researching current spatial trends and predicting how they can manifest in the built environment if they continue to persist. S.I.A. provides global and local foresight to create innovative insights that lead to the type of urbanity the city will need to change. S.I.A. focuses in particular on the topics of concern potentially needed to bring future spatial change to the city and takes an explicit universal approach to strategic planning by linking macro trends to local issues. S.I.A. aims to set an international agenda for research, design, and innovation for what society is, in particular, what the city, its products, architectures, landscapes, infrastructures, and networks could be; a blueprint for the next to come.

Projects (selection): Happy Bike City, Macuil Tochtli, Waalhaven, The Next City, Total Housing, NL28 Olympic Fire, EvoluCity - RDM Innovation&Science Center, Las Palmas Experience, Pleasure Edge, Talent Factory, M11, Satellite City
